Members of the list have rightly been sceptical of my find as it is almost =
unheard of in the West, if I had not seen it myself I would not have believ=
ed it either. I have seen many swords with Muromachi/Momoyama style koshira=
e over the years, but 99.9% have been 19th c. swords in retro style. Two ex=
ceptions come to mind: Victor Harris and I catalogued the blades in the Mus=
eum of Japanese Sword Fittings in Tokyo for Christie=92s in =9105. In that =
collection was a Momoyama tachi koshirae that was later sold in NY, the oth=
er was an itomaki tachi made for an Ikeda Daimyo in Christie=92s London. Vi=
ctor has seen this nagamaki and agrees that it is 16th c.  

I think this w=
eapon is the first of a number of identical contract pieces for an armoury,=
 as it is numbered =911' as are one seppa, the fuchi and the tsuka in ink u=
nder the fuchi, it is utilitarian, with thin yamagane mounts and low qualit=
y lacquer, the nakago-ana are not well made. The long ububa can be accounte=
d for by its lack of use, it may have been polished only once or twice then=
 stored for a very long time, this would account for its fairly good condit=
ion apart from the leather tsuka binding shrinking and being attacked by in=
sects.

It may look like a sword but it has the thick saya of a polearm, no=
 kurikata and the tsuka is 21.5" long. 

As I stated in my earlier post it =
weighs around 6lbs, this is not something one would want as a personal weap=
on, it is too heavy and awkward to carry and I think would only be useful i=
n battle.
